description:
Bartonella mastomydis is a species of bacteria belonging to the genus Bartonella. It is a gram-negative, intracellular, rod-shaped bacterium that primarily infects rodents, particularly the Asian house mouse (Mus musculus castaneus) and the Chinese white-bellied rat (Niviventer confucianus).

Bartonella mastomydis is transmitted through the bites or scratches of infected rodents, as well as through the feces of their ectoparasites, such as fleas and lice. The bacterium has the ability to invade and replicate within the endothelial cells of the host, leading to the development of various clinical manifestations, including fever, lymphadenopathy, and potentially more severe complications in immunocompromised individuals.

This species of Bartonella has been found in several regions of Asia, particularly in China, and its presence in rodent populations has implications for the potential transmission of zoonotic diseases to humans. Further research is ongoing to better understand the epidemiology, host-pathogen interactions, and the potential public health significance of Bartonella mastomydis.
